comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: The bust on the right might provide a clue, unless they are in the habit of moving busts around at Trinity College Library.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] I'd doubt that they do! Presuming this is Socrates?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: Possibly, but I suppose you have to visit TCL to be absolutely sure. Pictures of the Long Room are rare on the internet (as photography is not allowed there) and I don't remember it from my visit.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Tunney was very likely to visit the long room and would not have been out of place there at all at all!!  Famously while training for his great battle against Jack Dempsey one of the great US boxing writers found him reading Shakespeare and wondered if it was just for effect?  It wasn't!  Tunney was intelligent, literate and very well read and more than just a bruiser.  He has lots of relatives still in Ireland and they're no "daws" either!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] And from what I read about him in the Irish Independent reports of the visit, he was also very shy and quiet, hence not easy to interview for the newsmen who were far more used to very extrovert sportsmen...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Have a "mole" in Trinity College who's checking out the location of this one, and to confirm who the bust is of (terrible hanging preposition there, but you know what I mean)...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Proving that we have eyes and ears everywhere, our Mole in Trinity College can confirm that this photo was taken in Trinity College Long Room Library, and the bust is indeed that of Socrates...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: Luckily George Smiley isn't working at Trinity College Library...

comment.author: 75534057@N03
comment._content:
Hello, Trinity mole here. The man turning the pages has been identified as Alfred Charles de Burgh. He joined the  library in 1889 and held the post of Senior Library Assistant from 1899 to 1929.

Ps. Another candidate for page-turner was the then librarian, J.G. Smyly :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75534057@N03] Welcome, Trinity Mole - your information is making this photo's story a page turner! Couldn't resist...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] Smiley? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75534057@N03] Smyly? You just couldn't make this stuff up...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 59890603@N07
comment._content:
On the right by the window we see a camera man, this visit is being filmed.
Perhaps the footage is still around somewhere...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/1920sberlin] Good thinking! Couldn't find the Trinity visit, but Pathé have Gene Tunney at the Leopardstown Races. By the way, the "host" mentioned as Mr. McCormack is Count John McCormack, whose guest Gene Tunney was for the duration of his visit to Ireland...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 21717569@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] And how do you know on that...? (Evil smile)
